case_name: M s. Builders Supply Corporation v. Union of India

facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 824 of 1963 is an appeal from the judgment and order dated June 21, 1955 of the Calcutta High Court in Civil Revision Case No. 231 of 1954.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 824 of 1963. Appeal from the judgment and order dated June 21, 1955 of the Calcutta High Court in Civil Revision Case No. 231 of 1954. C. Das Gupta and Sukumar Ghose, for the appella

facts.text: The short question is whether respondent No. 1, the Union of India, is entitled to claim priority for tax due from respondent No. 2, M s. R. K. Das Co., for assessment years 1946-47 and 1947-48 over the decretal amount due to the appellant, M s. Builders Supply Corporation, from respondent No. 2.

anchor.surface_text: The short question of law which arises in this appeal is whether respondent No. 1, the Union of India, is entitled to claim that the tax due to it from respondent No. 2, M s. R. K. Das Co., on account of the assessment years 1946-47 and 1947-48 has priority and precedence over the decretal amount due to the appellant, M s. Builders Supply Corporation, from respondent No. 2.

facts.text: Respondent No. 2 secured a building contract from the Government in connection with the construction of the Mint and had to make a deposit of Rs. 50,000 as security.

anchor.surface_text: It appears that respondent No. 2 secured a building companytract from the Government in companynection with the companystruction of the Mint and in that behalf it had to make a deposit of Rs. 50,000 as security for the due execution of the companytract.

facts.text: Appellant obtained a supply of building materials from respondent No. 2 in connection with the execution of the contract.

anchor.surface_text: In companynection with the execution of the said, companytract, respondent No. 2 obtained a supply of building materials from the appellant.

facts.text: Appellant sued respondent No. 2 for recovery of dues and obtained an order for attachment before judgment of Rs. 5,000 out of the security deposit on 18th April, 1949.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant was unable to secure payment for the goods thus supplied by it, and so, it had to sue respondent No. 2 for recovery of the dues. In that suit, on the 18th April, 1949, the appellant obtained an order for attachment before judgment of Rs. 5,000 out of the aforesaid security deposit of Rs. 50,000.

facts.text: The deposit was lying with the Superintending Engineer, Calcutta Central Circle No. 1.

anchor.surface_text: This deposit was lying with the Superintending Engineer, Calcutta Central Circle No. 1.

facts.text: Appellant's suit was decreed by the 5th Additional Subordinate Judge, 24 Parganas, for Rs. 12,275-9-0 on 16th June, 1950.

anchor.surface_text: Subsequently, on the 16th June, 1950, the appellants suit was decreed by the 5th Additional Subordinate Judge, 24 Parganas, for a sum of Rs. 12,275-9-0.

facts.text: Appellant put the decree in execution on 14th February, 1952, in the court of the 7th Sub-Judge, starting Money Execution Case No. 9 of 1952.

anchor.surface_text: This decree was put in execution by the appellant on the 14th February, 1952, in the companyrt of the 7th Sub-Judge and in companysequence, Money Execution Case No. 9 of 1952 was started.

facts.text: Subordinate Judge issued order for attachment of further Rs. 7,275-9-0 out of the security deposit on 16th June, 1950 after decree.

anchor.surface_text: Four days thereafter, the Subordinate Judge issued an order for the attachment of a further sum of Rs. 7,275-9- 0 out of the aforesaid security amount deposited by respondent No. 2

facts.text: Subordinate Judge asked Superintending Engineer to remit Rs. 5,000 already attached before judgment.

anchor.surface_text: Whilst writing to the Superintending Engineer in that behalf, the Subordinate Judge asked him to remit to the companyrt the sum of Rs. 5,000 which had already been attached before judgment.

facts.text: Superintending Engineer placed further Rs. 7,275-9-0 under attachment but did not remit Rs. 5,000.

anchor.surface_text: On receiving this companymunication, the Superintending Engineer placed a further sum of Rs. 7,275-9-0 under attachment, but did number companyply with the requisition of the companyrt to remit Rs. 5,000 to it.

facts.text: On 30th April, 1952, Executing Court asked Superintending Engineer to transmit whole Rs. 12,275-9-0 but not complied till March 9, 1953.

anchor.surface_text: On the 30th April, 1952, the Executing Court wrote to the Superintending Engineer and asked him to transmit the whole of the amount of Rs. 12,275-9-0 which was under attachment as a result of the two previous orders passed in that behalf, but this requisition also was number companyplied with till March 9, 1953.

facts.text: Certificate Officer of 24 Parganas addressed letter to Subordinate Judge on 23rd July, 1952, requesting to withhold payment to appellant.

anchor.surface_text: Meanwhile, the Certificate Officer of 24 Parganas bad addressed a letter to the Subordinate Judge on the 23rd July, 1952, and requested him that if the Superintending Engineer had transmitted any money to his companyrt, its payment to the appellant should be withheld

facts.text: Certificate Officer sent copy of letter to Superintending Engineer asking not to make payment out of deposit but retain after deducting departmental dues.

anchor.surface_text: Along with that letter, the Certificate Officer sent a companyy of another letter which had been addressed by him to the Superintending Engineer asking him number to make any payment out of the amount deposited by respondent No. 2, but to retain it after deducting the departmental dues.

facts.text: Arrears of income-tax due from respondent No. 2 exceeded Rs. 50,000.

anchor.surface_text: The Superintending Engineer was informed by this letter that arrears of income- tax due from respondent No. 2 exceeded Rs. 50,000 with the result that the whole of the security deposit, less departmental dues, was liable to be applied to the satisfaction of the tax debt

facts.text: Superintending Engineer sent the whole attached amount to Executing Court, received on 9th March, 1953.

anchor.surface_text: In spite of this letter, however, the Superintending Engineer sent the whole of the amount attached at the instance of the appellant to the Executing Court and it was received in the Executing Court on the 9th March, 1953.

facts.text: On 21st March, 1953, Executing Court wrote to Certificate Officer requiring reason why amount should not be paid to appellant.

anchor.surface_text: On the 21st March, 1953, the Executing Court addressed a letter to the Certificate Officer in reply to the companymunication received by it from him, requiring him to state why the amount in question should number be paid to the appellant

facts.text: Commissioner of Income-tax intervened and moved for adjournments, intimating would show cause.

anchor.surface_text: At this stage, the Commissioner of Income-tax, representing respondent No. 1, intervened and moved the Executing Court for adjournment on several occasions. On every such occasion, the Commissioner intimated to the Executing Court that respondent No. 1 would show cause why the amount in question should number be paid to the appellant.

facts.text: On 17th June, 1953, Certificate Officer addressed letter under Rule 22 of Schedule II to Recovery Act asking court to hold amount.

anchor.surface_text: During the companyrse of these proceedings, on the 17th June, 1953, the Certificate Officer addressed a letter to the Executing Court under Rule 22 of Schedule 11 to the Public Demands Recovery Act  hereinafter called the Recovery Act  and asked the companyrt to hold the amount subject to further intimation from him.

facts.text: Letter received by Executing Court on 24th June, 1953, and order passed withholding payment to appellant.

anchor.surface_text: This letter was received by the Executing Court on the 24th June, 1953, and in companysequence, the Executing Court passed an order withholding payment to the appellant until further orders.

facts.text: On 15th July, 1953, respondent No. 1 made application to Executing Court claiming tax priority over judgment debt.

anchor.surface_text: Finally, on the 15th July, 1953, respondent No. 1 made an application to the Executing Court in which it claimed that the tax amount due to it from respondent No. 2 had a priority over the judgment debt due to the appellant from the same debtor

facts.text: Similar application by respondent No. 1 on 11th September, 1953 with details of income-tax demand and certificate under s.46(2) Income-tax Act forwarded to Collector.

anchor.surface_text: , and so, the whole of the amount under attachment ought to be paid to it towards partial satisfac- tion of the said income-tax dues. A similar application was made on the 11th September, 1953, and this application gave material details in respect of the income-tax demand against respondent No. 2.

facts.text: Executing Court upheld respondent No. 1's plea of priority and directed payment of Rs. 12,275-9-0 to respondent No. 1.

anchor.surface_text: In the result, the Executive Court upheld respondent No. 1s plea that the tax amount due to it from respondent No. 2 had a priority over the decretal amount due to the appellant from the same debtor and in companysequence, it issued a direction that the amount of Rs. 12,275-9-0 lying in its custody under attachment should be paid to respondent No. 1.

facts.text: Appellant challenged Executing Court's order by revision under S.115 CPC to Calcutta High Court.

anchor.surface_text: This order was challenged by the appellant before the Calcutta High Court by a revision application under S. 115 of the Code.

facts.text: Calcutta High Court discharged the rule in revision, holding respondent No. 1 entitled to priority.

anchor.surface_text: As a result of the findings, the High Court has discharged the rule which was issued at the instance of the appellant in the revision application preferred by it before the High Court under S. 115 of the Code.

The first point which falls for our decision in the present appeal is whether the High Court was right in holding that the common law doctrine about the priority of Crown debts on which the claim of respondent No. 1 was based, applied in the present case. This common law doctrine has no doubt been evolved by the special attributes associated with the Crown in England in early days.

concepts.interpretation: The doctrine applies in India as recognized by High Courts and continues under Art. 372(1); limited to tax dues priority over unsecured private debts.

anchor.surface_text: One of the grounds on which the validity of s. 46 (2) was challenged, was based on the fact that the recovery of arrears of income-tax is authorised to be made by S. 46 (2) in different modes and manners in the different States of India.

concepts.interpretation: Territorial classification in recovery procedures upheld as reasonable under Art.14 (citing Purshottam case).

anchor.surface_text: A public demand is defined by s. 3 (6) of this Act as meaning, inter alia, any arrear or money mentioned or referred-to in Schedule I and clause 3 of Sch. I deals, inter alia, with any money which is declared by any law for the time being in force to be recoverable or realizable as an arrear of revenue or land revenue.

concepts.interpretation: Brings tax arrears (via IT Act s.46(2)) within public demands recoverable under the Act.

interpretation_anchor.surface_text: as numberdifference of opinion on the question that Common law was included within the expression law in force used by Art. 372 1 . The majority judgm

anchor.surface_text: Section 46 (3) lays down that in any area with respect to which the Commissioner has directed that any arrears may be recovered by any process enforceable for the recovery of an arrear of any Municipal tax or local rate imposed under any enactment for the time being in force in any part of the State,

concepts.interpretation: Alternative recovery procedure; does not affect priority.

anchor.surface_text: Section 46 (5) provides yet another alternative remedy it lays down that if any arrear is in respect of any income chargeable under the head salaries the Income-tax Officer may require any person paying the same to deduct from any payment subsequent to the date of such requisition any arrears due from such an assessee

concepts.interpretation: Alternative remedy for salary arrears; part of multiple recovery modes, no impact on priority.
concepts.unlisted_description: Deduction at source for salary arrears

issues.text: whether the High Court was right in holding that the common law doctrine about the priority of Crown debts on which the claim of respondent No. 1 was based, applied in the present case

anchor.surface_text: The first point which falls for our decision in the present appeal is whether the High Court was right in holding that the common law doctrine about the priority of Crown debts on which the claim of respondent No. 1 was based, applied in the present case. This common law doctrine has no doubt been evolved by the special attributes associated with the Crown in England in early days.

issues.text: whether this doctrine of priority which is based on common law and which was recognised by our High Courts prior to 1950, can be said to constitute law in force in the territory of India at the relevant time within the meaning of Art. 372(1)

anchor.surface_text: The question which arises is whether this doctrine of priority which is based on common law and which was recognised by our High Courts prior to 1950, can be said to constitute law in force in the territory of India at the relevant time. In other words, is this doctrine of common law which was introduced in this country and followed, law in force within the meaning of Art. 372(1)?

issues.text: whether the provisions of s. 46 of the Income-tax Act and the relevant provisions of the Recovery Act can be said to amount to a statutory provision in respect of the doctrine of priority of arrears of income-tax due to respondent No. 1 over private debts due from the same debtor

anchor.surface_text: Having thus considered the broad features of the Recovery Act, the question which we have to decide is whether these provisions can be said to amount to a statutory provision in respect of the doctrine of priority of arrears of income-tax due to respondent No. 1 over private debts due from the same debtor.

holdings.text: The claim for priority made by respondent No. 1 in the present proceedings has to be sustained, because it is based on a Common law doctrine which had been applied and upheld in that part of India which was known British India prior to the Constitution.

anchor.surface_text: Our conclusion, therefore, is that the claim for priority made by respondent No. 1 in the present proceedings has to be sustained, because it is based on a Common law doctrine which had been applied and upheld in that part of India which was known British India prior to the Constitution.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Consistent recognition by Indian High Courts pre-1950, rooted in common law and historical jurisprudence including Hindu texts, undisputed before SC.

holdings.text: The rules of Common Law relating to substantive rights which had been adopted by this country and enforced by judicial decisions, amount to law in force in the territory of India at the relevant time within the meaning of Art. 372(1).

anchor.surface_text: Therefore, this decision clearly shows that the rules of Common Law relating to substantive rights which had been adopted by this country and enforced by judicial decisions, amount to law in force in the territory of India at the relevant time within the meaning of Art. 372 (1).

holdings.reasoning_summary: Per Director of Rationing case, common law on substantive rights like Crown priority is 'law in force' continued under Art.372(1); judicial decisions pre-Constitution bind.

holdings.text: s. 46 of the Income-tax Act does not deal with or provide for the principle of priority of tax dues and does not displace the common law doctrine.

anchor.surface_text: In making a provision for the recovery of arrears of tax, it cannot be said that s. 46 deals with or provides for the principle of priority of tax dues at all and so, it is impossible to accede to the argument that s. 46 in terms displaces the application of the said doctrine in the present proceedings.

holdings.reasoning_summary: s.46 provides procedural recovery modes as land revenue arrears, not addressing priority; alternative remedies do not abrogate common law prerogative.

holdings.text: The provisions of the Recovery Act do not amount to a statutory provision in respect of the doctrine of priority of arrears of income-tax over private debts; they merely provide recovery procedure.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Act consolidates procedural recovery for public demands including tax via s.46(2); no specific priority ordering like Companies Act s.230; Rule 22 enables priority determination but does not displace doctrine.

holdings.text: The High Court was right in coming to the conclusion that respondent No. 1 was entitled to claim priority in the matter of arrears of tax due from respondent No. 2 over the decretal debt due to the appellant from the same debtor.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Common law priority doctrine applies, continued under Art.372(1), not displaced by statutes; applies to facts where tax arrears precede unsecured decretal claim post-attachment.

holdings.text: Our present decision should be confined only to the narrow point... relating to respondent No. 1s claim that arrears of tax due to it have precedence or priority over money debts due to a private creditor from the same debtor.

anchor.surface_text: At this stage, we ought to make it clear that in the present appeal we are dealing with a very narrow point, and that relates to respondent No. 1s claim that arrears of tax due to it have precedence or priority over money debts due to a private creditor from the same debtor.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Explicitly limits scope to tax dues over unsecured private debts; future cases may differ for commercial debts, inter-state claims, etc.

precedents.citation: The Secretary of State in Council for India v. The Bombay Landing Shipping Co. Limited , 2 1868-69 5 Bom. H.C.R. p. 23.

anchor.surface_text: In The Secretary of State in Council for India v. The Bombay Landing Shipping Co. Limited , 2  Westropp, J. has elaborately examined this problem. The learned Judge held that a judgment debt due to the Crown was in Bombay entitled to the same

precedents.case_name: Secretary of State for India v. Bombay Landing Shipping Co. Ltd.
precedents.cited_proposition: Judgment debt due to the Crown entitled to precedence in execution as in England
precedents.cited_holding: a judgment debt due to the Crown was in Bombay entitled to the same precedence in execution as a like judgment debt in England

precedents.case_name: Bank of India v. John Bowman
precedents.cited_proposition: priority of Crown over subject debts of equal degree
precedents.cited_holding: the priority given to the Crown is not on the basis of its debt being a judgment debt or a debt arising out of statute, but the principle is that if the debts are of equal degree and the Crown and the subject are equal, the Crown's right will prevail

precedents.citation: Kaka Mohamed Ghouse Sahib Co. v. United Commercial Syndicate and Others, 1 1963 49 I.T.R. 824.

anchor.surface_text: In Kaka Mohamed Ghouse Sahib Co. v. United Commercial Syndicate and Others, 1  the Madras High Court has held that it is a settled principle of constitutional law that as between creditors of the same rank the Government is entitled to priority,

precedents.case_name: Kaka Mohamed Ghouse Sahib Co. v. United Commercial Syndicate
precedents.cited_proposition: Government entitled to priority over creditors of same rank; Republican Constitution does not abrogate
precedents.cited_holding: it is a settled principle of constitutional law that as between creditors of the same rank the Government is entitled to priority, and the Republican character of the Constitution of India has not abrogated this general doctrine of priority of State debts

anchor.surface_text: Our conclusion, therefore, is that the claim for priority made by respondent No. 1 in the present proceedings has to be sustained, because it is based on a Common law doctrine which had been applied and upheld in that part of India which was known British India prior to the Constitution.

That being so, we must hold that the High Court was right in coming to the conclusion that respondent No. 1 was entitled to claim priority in the matter of arrears of tax due from respondent No. 2 over the decretal debt due to the appellant from the same

Therefore, this decision clearly shows that the rules of Common Law relating to substantive rights which had been adopted by this country and enforced by judicial decisions, amount to law in force in the territory of India at the relevant time within the meaning of Art. 372 (1).

That being so, we must hold that the High Court was right in coming to the conclusion that respondent No. 1 was entitled to claim priority in the matter of arrears of tax due from respondent No. 2 over the decretal debt due to the appellant from the same
In making a provision for the recovery of arrears of tax, it cannot be said that s. 46 deals with or provides for the principle of priority of tax due

edges.explanation: Holding affirms concept interpretation that s.46 does not displace common law priority

anchor.surface_text: In making a provision for the recovery of arrears of tax, it cannot be said that s. 46 deals with or provides for the principle of priority of tax due

edges.explanation: Holding directly resolves issue by stating s.46 does not deal with or displace priority doctrine

anchor.surface_text: In making a provision for the recovery of arrears of tax, it cannot be said that s. 46 deals with or provides for the principle of priority of tax dues at all and so, it is impossible to accede to the argument that s. 46 in terms displaces the application of the said doctrine in the present proceedings.

That being so, we must hold that the High Court was right in coming to the conclusion that respondent No. 1 was entitled to claim priority in the matter of arrears of tax due from respondent No. 2 over the decretal debt due to the appellant from the same

edges.explanation: Holding h4 explicitly states that Recovery Act provisions (c12, Section 26) do not amount to a statutory provision respecting the doctrine of priority of tax arrears over private debts, undercutting any interpretation of c12 as establishing such priority.
Holding that Recovery Act provisions merely provide recovery procedure without amounting to statutory priority undercuts Rule 22 as establishing such priority.
Holding on Recovery Act provisions not amounting to priority statute addresses part of issue concerning Recovery Act
